All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.2: Sexual Prevention - Abstinence/Be Faithful. Activities (including training) to promote abstinence, fidelity, reducing multiple and concurrent partners, and related social and community norms that impact these behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. The Advancing Partners and Communities (APC) project, implemented by FHI 360, is designed to improve the overall health of communities and achieve other health-related impacts. This project will support the continuum of HIV care in communities, including linkage to care, retention in care, and adherence to therapy with proactive follow-ups. APC will be implemented at the community level through yet to be determined community-based organizations (CBOs), local leaders, and community members, who will be active participants in addressing the HIV/AIDS challenges that affect their communities. APC activities will target children, adolescent girls, their families and communities to increase their access to and uptake of HIV services, strengthen children’s resilience, and decrease gender-based violence, discrimination, and other barriers to HIV prevention, treatment, and care. To reach more people with care and treatment interventions, sub-partners will work closely with high volume facilities that will refer PLHIV in the pre-ART and ART phases to PEPFAR-supported community-based groups for ongoing monitoring and support, tracking of loss to follow ups, and adherence support. Provision of PHDP minimum package of services is also an important component of the APC project. FHI360 will implement these community-based interventions through local CBOs in seven districts: Francistown, Ghanzi, Kweneng East, Ngamiland, Serowe/Palapye, South East, and Southern.
